A 4-man dungeon is an instance designed for a party of four players, commonly used as a primary leveling method.
An Alliance Raid is a type of dungeon in FF14 that typically requires eight players working together to defeat bosses.
A 24-man raid is a large-scale instance requiring 24 players, usually referring to raids like the Crystal Tower series.
Raid is short for raid dungeon, usually referring to challenging instances that require multiple players (such as 8 or 24) to team up.
P1S stands for the first tier of the Eden's Gate: Resurrection Savage raid in FF14; 'S' denotes Savage difficulty.
P4S refers to the fourth tier of the Eden's Gate: Resurrection Savage raid in FF14; 'S' indicates Savage difficulty.
Savage raids are the highest difficulty raids in FF14, usually requiring eight players with complex mechanics and demanding tight team coordination.
In FF14, Battle Royale usually refers to the 'Crystalline Conflict' PvP mode where players fight in an arena until only one team remains.
A strategy team is a group of players dedicated to studying game mechanics and creating detailed guides.
A scenery enthusiast is a player who enjoys exploring beautiful locations and taking screenshots within the game.
A fashionista is a player who loves collecting and coordinating in-game outfits and glamour.
A casual player focuses on relaxing and enjoying the game without stressing over progression.
Fashion Report is an event in the Gold Saucer where players style outfits based on a theme to earn scores and rewards.
The Gold Saucer is a leisure and entertainment hub in FF14 offering mini-games, Fashion Report, and other activities.
A photo spot is a scenic or memorable location in the game where players often take screenshots.
A performance quest is a special type of quest in FF14 where players roleplay or perform as characters.
Side quests run parallel to the main story, enriching the world and offering extra rewards but are not required to progress the main plot.
Main quests are the primary missions that drive the storyline forward in FF14.
Trials are challenge instances where players face off against primal bosses from past expansions to earn rewards.
BiS gear refers to the best-in-slot equipment and stats for a character in the current patch, maximizing combat effectiveness.
Extreme trials are higher difficulty versions of primal fights, offering a tougher challenge.
Random queue refers to entering dungeons or raids through the matchmaking system without pre-forming a group.
Quick queue means entering an instance rapidly via the duty finder system.
A wipe caused by player error during an instance, resulting in the entire party being defeated.
The starting area is where new players begin their adventure in the game world.
Job change refers to switching between different combat or crafting classes in FF14.
A secondary job is any additional class a player learns besides their main job.
Gathering classes specialize in collecting resources, such as Botanist, Miner, and Fisher.
Crafting classes focus on creating items, including Carpenter, Blacksmith, Armorer, Goldsmith, Leatherworker, Weaver, Alchemist, and Culinarian.
The Firmament is a reconstruction project in Ishgard where players can contribute and participate.
Town NPCs are non-player characters in towns that provide quests, shops, or other services.
AFK means a player is idle or away from the keyboard, leaving their character online without active control.
A spammer is a player who repeatedly sends the same or similar messages in chat channels.
A toxic player behaves negatively or disruptively, negatively impacting others' gaming experience.
A roleplayer immerses themselves in character acting to enhance the game's storytelling and atmosphere.
Leeching refers to contributing minimally in group content, doing the bare minimum without active participation.
Boosting is when a player gains rewards in PvP or ranked events by minimal effort or relying heavily on teammates.
Taking damage means being hit by enemy attacks during combat.
Hate pull occurs when a non-tank player generates too much threat, causing enemies to switch targets from the tank to themselves.
Healing competition happens when multiple healers in a party compete over healing output.
Last hit stealing is when multiple DPS players compete to land the killing blow on enemies in raids or dungeons.
Early pull refers to a player starting the encounter before the rest of the party is ready, causing coordination issues.
Positioning error means a player is standing in the wrong spot during a fight, missing safe zones or mechanic requirements.
Callouts are player communications during raids to inform teammates about enemy abilities or mechanic locations.
Positioning refers to players standing in specific spots during encounters as dictated by mechanics.
Mechanic sharing involves multiple players distributing damage or effects from boss mechanics among themselves.
Collaboration events are special activities in FF14 featuring partnerships with other IPs or brands.
Collaboration mounts are unique mounts obtained through crossover events.
Collectibles are various items players can gather in FF14, including mounts, minions, and glamour pieces.
A story kill refers to a character's death or departure dictated by the storyline, usually unavoidable.
